original_title: Sri Lanka CB discontinues reimbursement of remittance transaction cost
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka Central Bank has discontinued the Reimbursement of  the Transaction Cost of Workers’ Remittances from this month citing incentives for foreign expatriate workers and exchange rate flexibility.

The central bank introduced the reimbursement of 1,000 rupees for every transaction by Sri Lankan expatriates from December 2021 after workers increasingly sought to send their earnings through informal methods like undiyal and hawala instead of formal bank networks.

“Considering the proposed incentives for migrant workers, great flexibility allowed in the foreign exchange market and the impact of this incentive on monetary base, the Monetary Board…..has decided to terminate the reimbursement of the transaction cost of workers’ remittances with effect from 01.05.2023,” the Central Bank said in a directive to banks.
The Central Bank in March last year allowed the flexibility in the rupee which later fell nearly 50 percent to 360 against US dollar from 200.
The monthly remittances inflows have recovered to pre-pandemic level and the government is now aiming to double it to $1 billion inflows from foreign remittances. (Colombo/May 12/2023)
